docs.lead_paragraph: The Cigna Corporation, the third-largest health insurer, said today that its fourth-quarter earnings dropped 25 percent, in part because of reduced international business, severance and other restructuring costs. The collapse of Enron was also a factor, Cigna said, reporting after-tax losses of $65 million primarily related to investment losses including, ''to a lesser extent,'' investments in Enron and in Argentine securities.
docs.abstract: Cigna Corp reports fourth-quarter net income fell to $191 million, down 25 percent from $277 million in 2000 period; reports after-tax losses of $65 million linked mainly to investment losses (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The house of a lesbian couple in Missoula was set on fire, days after they had been named as lead plaintiffs in a discrimination lawsuit against the state university system. The house was gutted. The women, Carla Grayson and Adrianne Neff, escaped the early morning fire with their infant child by climbing through a window. They had received death threats by mail after the suit had been filed. The suit said the university system had violated the rights of Ms. Grayson, a professor, by denying Ms. Neff health insurance and other benefits.

headline.main: National Briefing | Rockies: Montana: Fire At Lesbian Plaintiffs' House

docs.lead_paragraph: Global Crossing Faces 2 Federal Investigations Global Crossing, the fiber-optic network operator in bankruptcy court protection, is facing two federal investigations of its accounting practices. The inquiries come at a time when the collapse of Enron has led to increased concern among investors over accounting issues. The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun an inquiry into accusations that Global Crossing improperly inflated its revenue, the company disclosed yesterday. And law enforcement officials said that the F.B.I. was examining the company after receiving accusations of wrongdoing including fraudulent conduct. [Page A1.] A Push to Help the Uninsured A lobbying group that includes the United States Chamber of Commerce, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the American Medical Association is planning a campaign to push for measures intended to reduce the number of people without health insurance. Economists say that at least 40.4 million people are uninsured. [A12.]

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-6 Arabs Kill Israeli Woman In Jerusalem Park A group of Arab youths stabbed a 24-year-old Israeli woman to death in the Forest of Peace, a park set between Jewish and Arab areas of the city. In northern Israel, at least two Palestinians died when their car exploded. The Israeli police said the men apparently blew themselves up accidentally on their way to an attack. A6 Britain-Iran Relations Fray Iran rejected Britain's choice of ambassador when hard-line Iranian newspapers accused him of being ''a Jew'' and a spy. Britain retaliated by downgrading the status of the Iranian envoy and placing relations with Tehran on a ''more critical'' basis. A4

docs.lead_paragraph: At least two million people lost their health insurance in the last 13 months as unemployment rose and growing numbers of consumers decided they could not afford steeply rising costs. Health care economists said that at least 40.4 million Americans, based on conservative estimates, were uninsured by Jan. 31. Beyond the personal toll for people without coverage, the sharp increase in the number of uninsured Americans is a growing concern to employers, unions and providers of care. Some said they were worried that the trend would undermine the nation's employer-based health care system.

headline.main: Coalition Forms to Reverse Trend of Fast-Rising Ranks Of Uninsured Americans

docs.abstract: Unusually broad coalition of employers, unions, insurers, health care providers and consumer advocates plan advertising drive to gain support for national measures to halt sharp rise in number of Americans without health insurance; employers fear rise in health care costs as hospitals raise fees to reflect unpaid costs of uninsured emergency room patients (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Five-year-old Phoebe Kaufman's room was once filled with her artwork. Now all that remains is a single picture of a flower, which hangs by her bed. Her parents threw out everything else because paper is porous and might have absorbed dust from the collapsing World Trade Center towers that blasted into their Lower Manhattan apartment through an open window. No one knows whether Phoebe's artwork had become dangerous, and air tests done in that apartment building, about a block from ground zero, have shown the air to be safe. But decisions still had to be made, so everything absorbent -- stuffed animals, mattresses, coats -- went into the trash.

headline.main: With Uncertainty Filling the Air, 9/11 Health Risks Are Debated

docs.abstract: People who live within half mile of World Trade Center face series of questions and choices about how to live in altered place and how to assess environmental risks that proximity to disaster site and cleanup project may entail; community leaders estimate that 75 percent of roughly 20,000 people have returned to their homes since Sept 11 disaster; many residents face diversity of views about safety of air, and no answer seems certain, scientifically airtight or obvious; individual tenants, owners and workers have been left to determine for themselves how to clean contaminated apartment or office, whether to pay for expensive tests or filters, whether to worry about how well neighboring apartments or offices have been cleaned; residents with young children are particularly concerned about safety of their homes; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Palestinian State Likely, Sharon Affirms to Bush Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel reiterated that he expected to see a Palestinian state at the end of the Middle East peace process, and President Bush said Washington would maintain pressure on Yasir Arafat to crack down on Palestinian violence. A12 Passenger Storms Cockpit An unarmed passenger described as mentally disturbed or drunk tried to break down the door to the cockpit on a United Airlines flight from Miami to Buenos Aires, but was subdued and arrested upon landing. American and Argentine officials said there was no evidence suggesting terrorism. A6

docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city's budget deficit next year would be $4.5 billion, which is much worse than city budget officials previously feared. This latest figure is $500 million greater than Mr. Bloomberg's earlier estimate, and $1.6 billion more than the Giuliani administration forecasts when its officials left office on Dec. 31. The revised figure comes as the Bloomberg administration is putting the finishing touches on its first budget proposal, which he plans to unveil on Wednesday.

headline.main: Mayor's Deficit Estimate Grows to $4.5 Billion

docs.abstract: Mayor Michael Bloomberg announces New York City's deficit is expected to be $4.5 billion, much worse than budget officials previously feared (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: There is nothing like a truly contested election to put the usually somnolent New York State Legislature into a flurry of activity. With much back-slapping, the State Senate passed a good bill this week on women's health care that it had been stonewalling for years. This has everything to do with next Tuesday's special State Senate election on Manhattan's East Side, in which the Democratic candidate, Liz Krueger, has made the Senate's intransigence an issue. The Republican Senate majority, which is desperate to maintain its hold on that seat, suddenly dropped its longstanding opposition to the bill. But now the Democratic majority in the Assembly, with an eye on the same election, is trying to stall action. They should stop playing games and give it final passage. The bill, which has drawn intense criticism from the Catholic Church, requires companies to include coverage of birth control in their insurance plans. The Senate added a ''conscience clause'' permitting an exemption for situations in which a majority of those working or being served by an institution share the employer's religious beliefs, like churches themselves, or parochial schools. But the majority leader, Joseph Bruno, dropped his insistence that the bill also exempt religious institutions like hospitals and social service organizations that get public funds and employ people of all different faiths. The language adopted by the Senate is a good compromise, taken from a law that has already weathered the courts in California. The opportunity to pass a women's health bill may not last long, particularly if the Republicans lose the Senate race next week, which pits Ms. Krueger against the Republican Assemblyman John Ravitz. But the Assembly, probably hoping to keep Ms. Krueger's issue alive, has become the roadblock, insisting that the bill also include language eliminating insurance co-payment requirements for mammograms and pap smears. That is an issue that should be resolved later.
docs.abstract: Editorial says women's health bill being considered by New York State Legislature is being tied up in politics; notes bill requires companies to include coverage of birth control in their insurance plans; says Senate addition of 'conscience clause' permitting exemption for situations in which majority of those working or being served share employer's religious beliefs is good compromise; calls for passage of measure

docs.lead_paragraph: Staking out its legal position in an abortion case for the first time, the Bush administration asked the federal appeals court in Cincinnati this week to uphold Ohio's latest version of a ban on a medical procedure that opponents call partial-birth abortion. It is unusual, although not unprecedented, for the Justice Department to file a brief in a lower court case that does not directly involve a federal statute. President Bill Clinton twice vetoed bills to ban the procedure, and no federal statute deals with abortion techniques.

headline.main: U.S. Supports Bid to Uphold Ohio Limits On Abortions

docs.abstract: Bush administration asks federal appeals court in Cincinnati to uphold Ohio's latest version of ban on medical procedure that opponents call partial-birth abortion; it is unusual for Jsutice Dept to file brief in lower court case that does not directly involve federal statute; administration is for first time staking out its legal position in abortion case; Pres Clinton twice vetoed bills to ban procedure in question; no federal statute deals with abortion techniques (M)
